COVID-19 and/or asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2: Patient A, a 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension, presents with a persistent dry cough (severity rated 4/10) and generalized fatigue. The cough has been ongoing for the past 10 days and is not alleviated by over-the-counter cough remedies. He denies any shortness of breath at rest but reports mild exertional dyspnea. Additionally, the patient has noted a new-onset loss of taste and smell. On further inquiry, he admits to recent close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case. Notably, he is currently within the isolation period following the onset of symptoms.

Patient B, a 30-year-old female, is brought to the clinic due to persistent fever (temperature averaging 101°F) and profound fatigue. She describes her fatigue as debilitating, with a severity level of 8/10, significantly impacting her daily activities. The fever has been present for the past week and is not responsive to over-the-counter antipyretic medications. The patient denies any respiratory symptoms, cough, or shortness of breath. She has no significant medical history and is currently within the isolation period following the onset of her acute illness.

Patient C, a 55-year-old asymptomatic individual with known recent exposure to a confirmed COVID-19 case, seeks medical evaluation as part of the quarantine protocol. Despite the absence of overt symptoms, the patient's concern stems from the potential asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection. It is important to note that Patient C is currently within the quarantine period, following documented exposure to the virus.
